item.description:
"Climates", is the latest film from Turkish director Nuri Bilge Ceylan. I have seen his previous film "Distant" which I found to be an intriguing study of the cultural clash between town/city and tradition/Westernization.

"Climates", hailed as "the only masterpiece of the [2006 Cannes] festival" by the New York Foundation for the Arts, is the story of a searing relationship between a man and a woman (played by the director and his wife, Ebru Ceylan) that becomes a psychological portrait of an insecure man. At the close of her rave review, New York Times critic Manohla Dargis compares Ceylan to Michelangelo Antonioni, commenting that "while [Ceylan?s] films are similarly personal, they're more accessible? The mysteries of his work are those of the heart, the head, the soul." HFA Website

I saw Ceylan's previous movie "Distant" a couple of years ago at the MFA and was taken in by his tale of a villager who must move to Istanbul to find work and I'm really looking forward to seeing this, his newest film. Here, Ceylan plots the death of a relationship-ok, I admit not the cheeriest of subjects, but one that should provide an arena for discussion afterward.

Here is a review from The Chicago Tribune describing Climates "as sharp and lovely as the best Chekhov short stories." http://metromix.chica...

Tom will be holding a Meet-up sign near the front row after the film and then its off to a local restaurant to discuss.
item.name: Climates- A Drama from Turkey at HFA
